AdditionalFields.Value: Population Sciences,Prevention / Early Detection / Interception,Cancer Disparities

Description: The World Health Organization released a challenge to eliminate cervical cancer by implementing three strategies: vaccination for the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) in age-eligible males and females (90% goal in adolescents); age-appropriate cervical cancer screening with HPV-based testing (at least 70% up to date); and prompt and proper treatment of cervical abnormalities detected and cancers (90% resolved within 3 months). We have not realized these goals as uptake of these three pillars is not uniform nor widespread in two at-risk/vulnerable populations – minority and rural women in high income countries (HIC) and all women in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC). This session will provide an understanding of the causes of cervical cancer disparities in both HIC and LMIC, including a description of the populations at risk for cervical cancer in each type of country, as well as strategies to address these disparities, with specific attention to context, social determinants of health and culture.
SearchResultBody: FO10. Addressing Disparities in Cervical Cancer:  A Tale of Two Strategies
Title: Addressing Disparities in Cervical Cancer:  A Tale of Two Strategies
